> Is it possible to explain the rationale for leaving order.xml files
> beh=
ind? I know that we have some investment in the format, and though
> we can=
 of course move forward it is not clear to me from looking at
> the sheets.=


There were a number of reasons:

1. The XML wasn't well-defined for most =
modules, so the benefits of  
XML were mostly lost. Eg, it would be nice to=
 have

<FetchDNS>
<accept-non-dns-resolves>false</accept-non-dns-resolves>
=
<deciderules/>
<digest-algorithm>SHA1</digest-algorithm>
<digest-content>tr=
ue</digest-content>
<enabled>true</enabled>
</FetchDNS>

...so that configu=
ration sheets could be validated using standard XML  
tools. But that would=
 also be a huge departure from the existing  
order.xml, would require more=
 infrastructure, and would make it more  
difficult to support third-party =
modules.

2. XML's nesting provides a good visual sense of structure for th=
e  
old order.xml and for the new global sheet, but didn't work so well  
f=
or override sheets, which typically contain only a few settings.  
We'd eit=
her have to nest many levels of empty tags to get to the  
actual overrides=
, or have two different XML formats for the global  
sheet and override she=
ets.

3. The one-setting-per-line format plays well with command-line tools=
  
such as diff.

4. The one-setting-per-line format closely resembles the =
new JMX API  
for modifying sheets. In particular, code used for JMX transp=
ort of  
settings is re-used to read/write the sheet files.


>> In most ca=
ses the values for these new module settings are deduced
>> automatically b=
y the settings framework, so hopefully you won't have
>> to worry about the=
m. They are all listed in the Web UI and module
>> documentation though.
>
=
> Does this mean that there are sensible default values?

Yes; they default=
 to use the primary. See below.

> I=92m a little bit confused, still. I=92=
m looking at the global.sheet for
> profile-broad_but_shallow. Some of the =
items hold values:
> =91root:scope:rules:1:max-hops=3Dint, 2=92, and some d=
on=92t:
> =91root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers=3Dlist,
> java.=
lang.String=92. Is this second one an empty string? If so, how are
> lists =
defined?

The second one is not an empty string; it's saying "Create a new =
list  
that will only contain String values." To add an elements to the lis=
t  
you'd use:

root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers:0=3Dstring, =
audio/*;  
q=3D0.2, audio/basic
root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-head=
ers:1=3Dstring, text/*, text/ 
html, text/html;level=3D1


> Why is the con=
fig.txt file necessary?

It bootstraps the settings system. Since the setti=
ngs system itself  
uses a BDB, we needed a place to put the configuration =
for BDB.

> Can one define any settings in it?

No; the contents of config.=
txt are predefined. The valid properties  
are all listed in the file; anyt=
hing not listed is simply ignored.

> What is the difference between =91pri=
mary, org.archive[...]=92 and
> =91object, org.archive[...]=92?

Each class=
 of object can have one "primary" object nominated in the  
global sheet. I=
f  a setting uses the "primary" tag then the object  
created is registered=
 as the primary.

Primary objects are automatically selected as the default=
 value for  
most module settings. For instance, FetchHTTP has a server-cac=
he  
setting for specifying the ServerCache to use with FetchHTTP. The  
de=
fault value for that setting is to use the "primary" ServerCache.  
In this=
 way only one ServerCache instance needs to be specified in  
the sheet, an=
d all the modules that need it just find it.

-Paul
